Story:
My phone buzzed with a frantic call just as I was about to pick up my next passenger. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice shaky—his car had broken down on the highway, and he was stranded in the dark. “Can you come get me? Please, I don’t know who else to call,” he pleaded. My heart twisted; I knew how anxious he got in situations like this. But as I hung up, my taxi app pinged again. My passenger, already waiting, sent another message: “Where are you? I need to get to the hospital—please hurry!” 

I gripped the steering wheel, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing down. As a friend, I was supposed to drop everything and help Sam, especially in an emergency. But as a taxi driver, I had a duty to my passenger, who was counting on me for a safe, timely ride—maybe even something urgent. My mind raced, torn between loyalty and responsibility, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
